awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Multi-User Authentication and Access Control in the Internet of Things
awd_abstract_narration:
Computing is transitioning from single-user devices, such as laptops and phones, to the Internet of Things (IoT), in which numerous users interact with a particular device, such as an Amazon Echo or Internet-connected door lock. The desired level of access to particular capabilities, such as ordering items using a shared voice assistant, likely differs across members of a household (e.g., children and parents). Widely deployed devices and the existing research literature lack mechanisms for specifying who should be able to perform which actions with which household Internet-connected devices. Complicating matters, the users of a given device often have complex social relationships to each other. Our goal is to develop techniques and interfaces that enable non-technical users to specify who should be able to perform what actions using which Internet-connected devices in the home, as well as to verify the identity of the person trying to perform those actions. Misconfigured devices can open the home to attackers, yet may also disenfranchise members of the household. Our approach to authentication and authorization directly impacts security for consumers of an array of household IoT devices. A core objective of this proposal is also to train first-time student researchers in a tangible domain that is ideal for a first research experience.

On a technical level, the work comprises three phases. The first phase aims to characterize the access-control policies users will want to express for multi-user IoT devices, focusing on the unique characteristics and capabilities of the IoT. To do so, we will conduct an online user study that elicits users' desired access-control policies for the home IoT, that is, who should be allowed to use particular capabilities, as well as in what circumstances. Having identified the primitives necessary for users to express their desired access-control policies for the home IoT, the second phase will systematize authentication mechanisms and authorization interfaces appropriate for the constraints of these home IoT environments, proposing mechanisms commensurate with the risks of unauthorized use of different capabilities. In the third phase of the research, we will implement our proposed mechanisms and evaluate them through an in-situ field study, allowing us to gauge how effectively these interfaces and mechanisms minimize both unauthorized access and incorrect access denials in the realistic setting of users' homes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The world is transitioning from traditional single-user devices like computers and smartphones to household Internet of Things (IoT) devices. A few aspects of households make the use of these technologies very different than traditional devices. First of all, household devices are often shared by multiple family members, and they also lack the interface affordances — screens and keyboards — used to specify authentication and access-control policies for traditional devices.

 
Within this project, we accomplished a series of goals related to the project's intellectual merit via user studies, a literature systematization, and framework development. The first accomplishment was to better understand desired access-control policies, as well as means of expressing these policies, in the home IoT. We began by reenvisioning access control and authentication for the home IoT. In a 425-participant online user study, we found that desired access-control policies in the home are heavily context-sensitive. For example, we found that access control policies would often depend on the user's physical relationship to the device (e.g., in the same room or not), their past history of interacting with the device (e.g., the number of times they had performed some action with the device), the time of day, the cost of performing the attempted action, and many more. We also found that access-control policies depended heavily on the relationship between the homeowner and the person trying to perform a particular action. From these desired policies, we identified likely candidates for default policies. We also identified necessary primitives for specifying more complex, yet desirable, access-control policies. These primitives ranged from the time of day to the current location of users.


Building on this need for primitives supporting contextual access-control policies, our second accomplishment was to understand how to authenticate the sensor readings that underpin contextual access-control policies. The vast literature on context sensing could potentially be leveraged to support contextual access control, yet this literature mostly ignores privacy, attacks, and adversaries. We reevaluated the literature on home context sensing to understand the tradeoffs among privacy, security, and usability. We described a novel threat model in smart homes focusing on non-technical adversaries. We then leveraged literature systematization to construct a decision framework for home context sensing that considers privacy, security, and usability. We found some desired contexts are either hard to sense in a privacy-preserving way or have significant trade-offs in security and usability. Many sensors collect more data than needed, yet are not effective for all groups of users or all situations. Some sensors are susceptible to simple threats like physical denial-of-service attacks, making it easy to bypass policies dependent on the absence of a characteristic.


Our third and final intellectual accomplishment developed novel algorithms for automatically creating firewall-style rules for home IoT devices. To protect users from malicious security and privacy behaviors of such devices, it is crucial to understand what the expected behaviors on a network should be within the context of device access control. Our approach was to create methods to automatically generate firewall-style rules by simply observing the network traffic of other households' instances of these same devices behaving correctly. As part of this objective, we answered questions about how to generalize these observations from other households and how many other devices were needed to create sufficiently generalizable rules.

 

While these findings' broader impacts implications for redesigning widespread home IoT systems, our project also had important broader impacts for education. Numerous students, including Ph.D. students, undergraduates, and high school students, were trained in robust research methods and user-centered approaches to security and privacy as critical parts of the research itself. Many of these students are now using their security and privacy knowledge in the U.S. technology industry or as part of their further academic education.
